We treat the observation of a specific number of individuals as a Poisson-distributed variable with parameter λ in each time bin. The probability of finding an individual of species i in time bin j is then p ij = 1 − exp(− λ ij ), and thus λ ij = −ln(1 − p ij ). In practice, p ij is estimated as y ij / n j , where y ij is the number of sites in which species i is observed at time bin j and n j is the number of sites in that time bin where at least one of the species included in the analysis is observed. SCOR is the total density of a given set of m j species in a time bin,
